awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Supporting Healthy Development of Infants in Contexts of Poverty and Homelessness
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate developmental processes of risk and resilience among infants whose families are homeless and have very low income. The project will contribute to the limited knowledge of well-being of homeless infants. Infants are overrepresented among children experiencing homelessness but underrepresented in the research literature. Furthermore, the project will expand basic understanding of the risks associated with homelessness compared to risks of poverty more generally, and it will inform efforts on the part of service providers and policymakers to support healthy development of infants and families through parenting programs. The project will involve the design and evaluation of a child development curriculum for family housing providers. This curriculum will be delivered by graduate students, enhancing the students' education while simultaneously enhancing knowledge of developmental science among service providers who interact daily with young children and families experiencing homelessness.

Research participants will include infants and their parents who are staying in emergency homeless shelters or who are housed in similar neighborhoods with very low incomes. Families from shelters will be randomly assigned either to a brief parenting intervention or to care-as-usual. Researchers will assess and compare the well-being of children and parents in terms of infant development, parent functioning, and quality of the parent-child relationship at three time-points over eight months to observe change in functioning over time and in relation to participation in the parenting intervention. The researchers hypothesize that families experiencing homelessness will have more difficulties than very low-income, housed families, but that nurturing parent-child relationships will predict better adjustment over time in both groups. Furthermore, researchers expect to see improvements in infant well-being, parent functioning, and parent-child relationships among families who receive the parenting intervention while staying in shelters.

por.por_cntn:
Infants staying in family homeless shelters already show developmental delays. Nevertheless, it matters what families, shelters, and other systems do. There are important ways to support babies and their caregivers to promote resilience, like encouraging social support for parents, training shelter staff in early development and adversity, and providing interventions that are intentional, formal, and supported by research evidence. We had four goals for this project: (1) understand the developmental wellbeing of infants experiencing homelessness, (2) test an intervention for parents of infants in shelters, (3) identify factors accounting for risk and resilience, and (4) enrich shelter settings for infants by teaching staff about early childhood development. 

For Goals 1-3, we used a sample of 106 infants (ages 1-12 months) and their caregivers staying in family shelters in the Philadelphia area. We met with families up to three times over 8 months for repeated assessments of infant, parent, and family wellbeing. We assessed infants’ developmental progress in motor and language skills, social-emotional skills, and behavioral and physiological responses to stress. For parents, we measured mental health, parenting stress, history of adverse experiences, and access to social support. Family wellbeing included risk factors as well as quality of the parent-infant relationship, observed by asking parents to play with their babies for fifteen minutes.We randomly selected fifty families to receive a brief parenting intervention called My Baby’s First Teacher (MBFT) between the first and second assessments. Shelter staff facilitated MBFT using a manual and video-guided lessons over five weeks. Parents met in small groups with their infants to learn about infant brain development, motor skills, language, bonding and attachment, and to practice activities like tummy time, infant massage, and face-to-face responsive play.

We investigated developmental status by combining assessment scores from shelter infants with previous pilot data on other young children in shelter (n=128). Overall, scores were significantly below age-based norms for language and motor development. Over 2 months, growth in scores was slower than expected. Initial scores and changes were associated with family factors: positive parenting and parent education level predicted better infant development while parent depression predicted worse. These delays are likely related to risks associated with poverty generally and homelessness specifically. 

The link between infant development and parent factors fits with what we learned about the MBFT parenting intervention. Positive responsiveness in parent-infant interactions increased for families assigned to MBFT compared to those who were not. The parent’s history of adversity was associated with parenting and infant wellbeing in several ways. Parents who experienced more adversity recently had higher depression symptom scores, and more adversity in parents’ own childhoods was linked with more positive parent-infant relationships, but only when parents had access to high levels of social support. Parent depression symptoms were lower for parents with more social support, highlighting social support as a key resilience factor. Preliminary analyses of infant salivary cortisol (44 infants), we found effects of parent adversity on infant physiology: infants whose parents had more adverse experiences showed more dramatic stress responses. Together these findings shed light on developmental processes of parenting by identifying how parent adversities are associated with infant wellbeing in the context of extreme poverty and homelessness.

Finally, we developed workshops to teach shelter staff about early childhood development, both broadly and in relation to adversity and homelessness. In the planning phase, we gathered information about family and staff experiences in shelters to understand strengths and needs. Parents’ perception of support in shelter uniquely predicted better child wellbeing, beyond effects of parenting stress. With a national phone survey of over 70 staff working in family shelters, we learned that shelter staff wanted more training on early childhood development including topics of typical development, parenting, and impacts of trauma. Through my research lab and a graduate course on translational developmental science, I guided student researchers in designing a 6-module workshop series in response. We tested elements with focus groups before delivering the series to a group of 11 staff from 6 different family shelters. All responded positively, indicating they were satisfied with the series and would recommend it. Attendees improved in their understanding of early childhood development.

We published findings in scholarly journals (e.g., Halverson et al., 2024; Herbers et al., 2023; 2020; Herbers & Henderson, 2019; Mulvey et al., 2023; Vrabic et al., 2022) and presented at local, national, and international conferences targeting both researchers and practitioners. Homelessness is a pressing social issue, even more relevant because of social and economic changes following the COVID-19 pandemic. Understanding the threats posed by housing instability and the factors that support resilience in early development have implications for basic developmental science and for social action to prevent and reduce risks while bolstering strengths that enable children and families to thrive.
